Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how language expresses and creates personal and social identities
Elaboration: Understanding local idioms and discussing their connection with personal and social identities
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •learning about specific idioms and their origins

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how language expresses and creates personal and social identities
Elaboration: Understanding local idioms and discussing their connection with personal and social identities
EALDElaboration: •support to interpret tone and word choice

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how language expresses and creates personal and social identities
Elaboration: Developing dialogue that reveals character in comics, cartoons and animations

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Recognise language used to evaluate texts including visual and multimodal texts, and how evaluations of a text can be substantiated by reference to the text and other sources
Elaboration: Building knowledge about words of evaluation, including words to express emotional responses to texts, judgement of characters and their actions, and appreciation of the aesthetic qualities of text
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •creating a word cline of evaluative language encountered in texts studied in class, e.g. ‘interesting’, ‘diverting, ‘compelling’ to explicitly demonstrate the strength, intensity and inference that words carry

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Recognise language used to evaluate texts including visual and multimodal texts, and how evaluations of a text can be substantiated by reference to the text and other sources
Elaboration: Analysing how evaluative language can be used to assess the qualities of a narrative or persuasive text; for example, its impact on the reader or the author's skill in the use of language

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Recognise language used to evaluate texts including visual and multimodal texts, and how evaluations of a text can be substantiated by reference to the text and other sources
Elaboration: Recognising how evaluative language is used to critically assess the validity of evidence and the reliability of sources

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify and describe how texts are structured differently depending on their purpose and how language features vary in texts
Elaboration: Examining the structures of book or film reviews and how they might move from description of context to summary of the text and then to judgement of the text
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •model texts and instruction to demonstrate and explain the different stages and different language features in different types of texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify and describe how texts are structured differently depending on their purpose and how language features vary in texts
Elaboration: Recognising the social purpose of a persuasive text and how the purpose is reflected in the text structure and by the language features; for example, analysing the structure and language features of advertising posters

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify and describe how texts are structured differently depending on their purpose and how language features vary in texts
Elaboration: Describing the structure and language features of literary texts, arguments, discussions, creative and analytical responses to literary texts, films or popular media, and discussing how the structure and language serves the purpose of the text

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand that the cohesion of texts relies on devices that signal structure and guide readers, such as overviews and initial and concluding paragraphs
Elaboration: Comparing and analysing the structure of media texts such as digital news sites or print media, identifying strategies used to create cohesion
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •model texts and instruction to demonstrate and explain how cohesive devices are used in before collaborating in small groups to deconstruct cohesion in a range of texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand that the cohesion of texts relies on devices that signal structure and guide readers, such as overviews and initial and concluding paragraphs
Elaboration: Identifying how authors foreshadow how a text will unfold; for example, identifying the topic sentence, sentence openers and text connectives

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand how complex and compound-complex sentences can be used to elaborate, extend and explain ideas
Elaboration: Identifying and experimenting with a range of clause structures and discussing the effect of these in the expression and development of ideas
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •multiple opportunities to practise deconstructing sentences and identifying clause structure, with the complexity of the sentences appropriate to students’ level of English language proficiency

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand how complex and compound-complex sentences can be used to elaborate, extend and explain ideas
Elaboration: Consolidating knowledge of simple, compound and complex sentences, recognising that a simple sentence can express sophisticated ideas and a complex sentence need not express "complex" ideas

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand how complex and compound-complex sentences can be used to elaborate, extend and explain ideas
Elaboration: Examining the addition of ideas using a complex-compound sentence; for example, "when dinosaurs roamed the earth, weather patterns shifted significantly and as a result vegetation depleted."

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand how consistency of tense through verbs and verb groups achieves clarity in sentences
Elaboration: Identifying and discussing how verb tense is maintained in compound, complex and compound-complex sentences
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •modelling of verb forms during learning activities to develop a bank of verbs and their different forms which allow for greater linguistic choice

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand how consistency of tense through verbs and verb groups achieves clarity in sentences
Elaboration: Identifying and discussing how verb tense is maintained in compound, complex and compound-complex sentences
EALDElaboration: •multiple opportunities to identify verb tense across a text and discuss how verb tense is maintained in sentences

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand how consistency of tense through verbs and verb groups achieves clarity in sentences
Elaboration: Identifying and discussing different forms of verb tenses and their use to maintain consistency of tense in different sentences; for example, "i organise the cake stall every week, and i am running the meeting this weekend, as well."

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Analyse how techniques such as vectors, angle and/or social distance in visual texts can be used to create a perspective
Elaboration: Comparing how perspectives are created in animations and advertisements
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •modelling the deconstruction of visual texts and inclusion of texts representing a range of cultural contexts

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Analyse how techniques such as vectors, angle and/or social distance in visual texts can be used to create a perspective
Elaboration: Comparing how different advertisements advertise the same product, using techniques to create different perspectives for effect

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Analyse how techniques such as vectors, angle and/or social distance in visual texts can be used to create a perspective
Elaboration: Analysing how the illustrations in picture books, graphic novels and advertisements use size, colour, angle, proximity, vector and salience to influence the reader

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Investigate the role of vocabulary in building specialist and technical knowledge, including terms that have both everyday and technical meanings
Elaboration: Recognising vocabulary used to represent high utility, abstract academic concepts; for example, "factor", "hypothesise", "issue" and "critique"
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •using bilingual dictionaries to link learning to existing knowledge in students’ home language; use of visual support; use of concept maps to show related vocabulary; use of word charts showing the verb form and the nominalisation

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Investigate the role of vocabulary in building specialist and technical knowledge, including terms that have both everyday and technical meanings
Elaboration: Identifying vocabulary used to write about a topic; for example, using terms for poetic devices and words to explain the effects of the devices in poems

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand the use of punctuation including colons and brackets to support meaning
Elaboration: Examining the impact of information added to sentences when colons and brackets are used
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •models and explanations of the use of brackets and colons and multiple opportunities to practise deconstructing examples in use and explaining the impact or effect of the extra information provided

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify and explore ideas, points of view, characters, events and/or issues in literary texts, drawn from historical, social and/or cultural contexts, by first nations australian, and wide-ranging australian and world authors
Elaboration: Exploring ideas about heroism in literary texts by wide-ranging world authors
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •use of visuals and explanation so students understand the contexts and background knowledge of the texts which may include opportunities to share and compare insights from texts read in their home language about the ideas, points of view, characters, events and/or issues related to these texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify and explore ideas, points of view, characters, events and/or issues in literary texts, drawn from historical, social and/or cultural contexts, by first nations australian, and wide-ranging australian and world authors
Elaboration: Exploring ideas about heroism in literary texts by wide-ranging world authors
EALDElaboration: •wherever possible use a text by an Australian author or illustrator of that cultural background

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify and explore ideas, points of view, characters, events and/or issues in literary texts, drawn from historical, social and/or cultural contexts, by first nations australian, and wide-ranging australian and world authors
Elaboration: Discussing the similarities and differences in character representations in film adaptations of novels and plays

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify and explore ideas, points of view, characters, events and/or issues in literary texts, drawn from historical, social and/or cultural contexts, by first nations australian, and wide-ranging australian and world authors
Elaboration: Exploring representations of characters and events in literary texts by first nations australians

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify and explore ideas, points of view, characters, events and/or issues in literary texts, drawn from historical, social and/or cultural contexts, by first nations australian, and wide-ranging australian and world authors
Elaboration: Exploring depictions of the city or the bush in australian poems and short stories from different eras

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Form an opinion about characters, settings and events in texts, identifying areas of agreement and difference with others' opinions and justifying a response
Elaboration: Establishing forums and criteria for discussing the relative merits of characters, settings and events in literary texts
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •models of language required to both state an opinion and to respectfully agree with others

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Form an opinion about characters, settings and events in texts, identifying areas of agreement and difference with others' opinions and justifying a response
Elaboration: Comparing personal opinions on texts and justifying responses in discussions which may include referencing behaviours such as integrity and loyalty

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Explain the ways that literary devices and language features such as dialogue, and images are used to create character, and to influence emotions and opinions in different types of texts
Elaboration: Comparing the representation of a character's appearance in a novel and film version of the same text
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •deconstructing and exemplifying literary devices and language features that are used to create character

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Explain the ways that literary devices and language features such as dialogue, and images are used to create character, and to influence emotions and opinions in different types of texts
Elaboration: Comparing the representation of a character's appearance in a novel and film version of the same text
EALDElaboration: •opportunities for students to demonstrate their understanding through image

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Explain the ways that literary devices and language features such as dialogue, and images are used to create character, and to influence emotions and opinions in different types of texts
Elaboration: Explaining the impact and significance of language features in a text

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Discuss the aesthetic and social value of literary texts using relevant and appropriate metalanguage
Elaboration: Determining criteria for evaluating the aesthetic value of a literary text and share opinions

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Discuss the aesthetic and social value of literary texts using relevant and appropriate metalanguage
Elaboration: Comparing a film adaptation of a literary text using specific language for naming the text structure, literary devices and language features of film and novels, and sharing opinions about the aesthetic and social value of each

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify and explain the ways that characters, settings and events combine to create meaning in narratives
Elaboration: Analysing and explaining the structure and features of short stories, discussing the purposes and appeal of different authorial choices for structure
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •opportunities to represent understandings of character, setting and events visually

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify and explain the ways that characters, settings and events combine to create meaning in narratives
Elaboration: Exploring traditional stories from asia and discussing their features; for example, use of the oral mode, visual elements and verse to convey the narrative

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify and explain how literary devices create layers of meaning in texts including poetry
Elaboration: Explaining the sound and rhythm of poetry using metalanguage; for example, "end and internal rhyme", "meter" and "alliteration", and discussing how layers of meaning are created

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify and explain how literary devices create layers of meaning in texts including poetry
Elaboration: Viewing or reading first nations australian films, plays and poetry, and explaining the layers of meaning created by imagery

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and edit literary texts that experiment with language features and literary devices encountered in texts
Elaboration: Using aspects of texts in imaginative recreations such as re-situating a character from a text into a new situation
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •modelling, deconstructing and joint constructions to scaffold a focus language feature or literary device.

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and edit literary texts that experiment with language features and literary devices encountered in texts
Elaboration: Creating a prequel using an imagined series of life events of a character presented as a series of flashbacks in a scripted monologue

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and edit literary texts that experiment with language features and literary devices encountered in texts
Elaboration: Creating chapters for an autobiography, short story or diary

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and edit literary texts that experiment with language features and literary devices encountered in texts
Elaboration: Experimenting with different narrative structures such as the epistolary form, flashback and multiple narrators

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and edit literary texts that experiment with language features and literary devices encountered in texts
Elaboration: Experimenting with imagery, sentence variation, metaphor and word choice when creating a literary text

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and edit literary texts that experiment with language features and literary devices encountered in texts
Elaboration: Transforming familiar print narratives into short video or film narratives, drawing on knowledge of the type of text and possible adaptations to setting for a new mode

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explain the effect of current technology on reading, creating and responding to texts including media texts
Elaboration: Investigating the influence of communicative technologies such as sms, email and gifs on written language
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •opportunities to discuss the influence of communicative technologies using their home language and development of a bank of terms they can use to discuss the issues in English

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explain the effect of current technology on reading, creating and responding to texts including media texts
Elaboration: Analysing the impact of interactive elements of digital texts on texts such as magazines read in a digital form

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explain the effect of current technology on reading, creating and responding to texts including media texts
Elaboration: Identifying changes in topics considered to be newsworthy as a result of technological change

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills when discussing and presenting ideas and information including evaluations of the features of spoken texts
Elaboration: Participating in pair, group, class, school and/or community speaking and listening situations, including informal conversations, discussions, debates and presentations
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •modelling and rehearsing effective language for dialogue and discussion including different question forms, sentence starters and evaluative language used in relation to spoken texts, for example ‘powerful’, ‘clear’, ‘persuasive’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills when discussing and presenting ideas and information including evaluations of the features of spoken texts
Elaboration: Using effective strategies for dialogue and discussion in a range of formal and informal contexts, including speaking clearly and coherently and for an appropriate length, clarifying and rephrasing comments of others

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills when discussing and presenting ideas and information including evaluations of the features of spoken texts
Elaboration: Identifying key evidence supporting an argument in a discussion between 2 speakers

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills when discussing and presenting ideas and information including evaluations of the features of spoken texts
Elaboration: Choosing vocabulary and sentence structures for purposes and audiences, adapting language choices to meet the perceived audience needs

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills when discussing and presenting ideas and information including evaluations of the features of spoken texts
Elaboration: Ensuring that ways of communicating for particular audiences are acknowledged

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse the ways in which language features shape meaning and vary according to audience and purpose
Elaboration: Explaining the relationship between language features, and audience and purpose, such as identifying which group would be the most likely target audience for the information in an advertisement and justifying why
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •close analysis of different language features used in a range of short texts on the same topic and how the language features change according to audience and purpose, for example a text message to a friend, an email to a parent, a speech to a group of teachers

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse the ways in which language features shape meaning and vary according to audience and purpose
Elaboration: Examining depictions of the histories and cultures of first nations australians, discussing language features that shape meaning

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explain the structure of ideas such as the use of taxonomies, cause and effect, extended metaphors and chronology
Elaboration: Identifying cause and effect in explanations and how these are used to convince an audience of a course of action
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •use of visuals such as concept maps to show how ideas are related in a text •scaffolded activities to trace a metaphor throughout a text

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring, questioning and inferring to analyse and summarise information and ideas
Elaboration: Comparing the presentation of ideas in formal and informal speeches and determining the reasons for the differences
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •use of visuals such as graphic organisers or retrieval charts to help students identify and organize ideas. demonstrations of, and opportunities to practice how to draw inferences, for example ‘The door opened, and a cooling wind came in.’ The inference is that the weather is fresh and cool outside.

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring, questioning and inferring to analyse and summarise information and ideas
Elaboration: Analysing visual features including choice of image, colour, composition and font in covers of different editions of books when predicting the tone of a text

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring, questioning and inferring to analyse and summarise information and ideas
Elaboration: Determining and summarising the key idea(s) of paragraphs and chapters in an extended text

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, edit and publish written and multimodal texts, selecting subject matter, and using text structures, language features, literary devices and visual features as appropriate to convey information, ideas and opinions in ways that may be imaginative, reflective, informative, persuasive and/or analytical
Elaboration: Compiling a portfolio of texts in a range of modes related to a particular concept, purpose or audience; for example, a class anthology of poems or stories
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •teacher modelling, deconstruction and joint construction of new types of texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, edit and publish written and multimodal texts, selecting subject matter, and using text structures, language features, literary devices and visual features as appropriate to convey information, ideas and opinions in ways that may be imaginative, reflective, informative, persuasive and/or analytical
Elaboration: Compiling a portfolio of texts in a range of modes related to a particular concept, purpose or audience; for example, a class anthology of poems or stories
EALDElaboration: •guided or shared editing of texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, edit and publish written and multimodal texts, selecting subject matter, and using text structures, language features, literary devices and visual features as appropriate to convey information, ideas and opinions in ways that may be imaginative, reflective, informative, persuasive and/or analytical
Elaboration: Using appropriate text conventions to create scripts for interviews, presentations, advertisements, radio segments, podcasts, digital and online reflections including vlogs

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, edit and publish written and multimodal texts, selecting subject matter, and using text structures, language features, literary devices and visual features as appropriate to convey information, ideas and opinions in ways that may be imaginative, reflective, informative, persuasive and/or analytical
Elaboration: Editing for meaning by removing unnecessary repetition, reordering sentences and varying sentence structures to refine ideas, adding or substituting words for impact, and reviewing accuracy of grammar, spelling and punctuation

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, edit and publish written and multimodal texts, selecting subject matter, and using text structures, language features, literary devices and visual features as appropriate to convey information, ideas and opinions in ways that may be imaginative, reflective, informative, persuasive and/or analytical
Elaboration: Tracking a word-processed document to jointly edit texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, rehearse and deliver presentations for purposes and audiences in ways that may be imaginative, reflective, informative, persuasive and/or analytical, by selecting text structures, language features, literary devices and visual features, and using features of voice including volume, tone, pitch and pace
Elaboration: Preparing a presentation combining print, visual and audio elements to explore and interpret ideas, drawing on knowledge and research about ideas and opinions different from students' own
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •the opportunity to present in smaller groups to build their confidence

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, rehearse and deliver presentations for purposes and audiences in ways that may be imaginative, reflective, informative, persuasive and/or analytical, by selecting text structures, language features, literary devices and visual features, and using features of voice including volume, tone, pitch and pace
Elaboration: Preparing a presentation combining print, visual and audio elements to explore and interpret ideas, drawing on knowledge and research about ideas and opinions different from students' own
EALDElaboration: •opportunities to view and deconstruct language, visual and audio features of model presentations

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, rehearse and deliver presentations for purposes and audiences in ways that may be imaginative, reflective, informative, persuasive and/or analytical, by selecting text structures, language features, literary devices and visual features, and using features of voice including volume, tone, pitch and pace
Elaboration: Selecting features of voice, such as tone, volume, pitch and pace, for different audiences and purposes, recognising the effects these have on audience understanding and engagement

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, rehearse and deliver presentations for purposes and audiences in ways that may be imaginative, reflective, informative, persuasive and/or analytical, by selecting text structures, language features, literary devices and visual features, and using features of voice including volume, tone, pitch and pace
Elaboration: Monitoring ideas developed at each stage of creating a presentation in a blog or journal

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, rehearse and deliver presentations for purposes and audiences in ways that may be imaginative, reflective, informative, persuasive and/or analytical, by selecting text structures, language features, literary devices and visual features, and using features of voice including volume, tone, pitch and pace
Elaboration: Sharing feedback with a peer while planning, creating and rehearsing a presentation

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how to use spelling rules and word origins; for example, greek and latin roots, base words, suffixes, prefixes and spelling patterns to learn new words and how to spell them
Elaboration: #VALUE!
